column1: Paducah () is a home rule-class city in and the county seat of McCracken County
column2: Kentucky
column3: United States. The largest city in the Jackson Purchase region
column4: it is located at the confluence of the Tennessee and the Ohio rivers
column7: to the northwest and Nashville
column9: to the southeast. The population was 24
column12: 024 during the 2010 U.S. Census. Twenty blocks of the city's downtown have been designated as a historic district and listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: Paducah is the hub of its micropolitan area
column2: which includes McCracken
column3: Ballard and Livingston counties in Kentucky and Massac County in Illinois.

column1: Paducah was first settled as "Pekin" around 1821 by European Americans James and William Pore. The town was laid out by explorer and surveyor William Clark in 1827 and renamed Paducah.
Although local lore long connected this name to an eponymous Chickasaw chief "Paduke" and his band of "Paducahs"
column2: authorities on the Chickasaw have since said that there was never any chief or tribe of that name
column3: or anything like it. The Chickasaw language does not have related words. Instead
column4: historians believe that Clark named the town for the Comanche people of the western plains. They were known by regional settlers as the Padoucas
column5: from a Spanish transliteration of the Kaw word Pádoka or the Omaha Pádoⁿka.)

column2: steamboats and railroads ===

column1: Paducah was formally established as a town in 1830 and incorporated as a city by the state legislature in 1838. By this time
column2: steam boats traversed the river system
column3: and its port facilities were important to trade and transportation. In addition
column4: developing railroads began to enter the region. A factory for making red bricks
column5: and a foundry for making rail and locomotive components became the nucleus of a thriving "River and Rail" economy.

column1: Paducah became the site of dry dock facilities for steamboats and towboats
column2: and thus headquarters for many barge companies. Because of its proximity to coalfields further to the east in Kentucky and north in Illinois
column3: Paducah also became an important railway hub for the Illinois Central Railroad. This was the primary north-south railway connecting the industrial cities of Chicago and East St. Louis to the Gulf of Mexico at Gulfport
column4: Mississippi and New Orleans
column5: Louisiana. The Illinois Central system also provided east-west links to the Burlington Northern and the Atchison
column7: and Santa Fe Railways (which later merged to become the BNSF Railway).

column1: In 1924 the Illinois Central Railroad began construction at Paducah of their largest locomotive workshop in the nation. Over a period of 190 days
column2: a large ravine between Washington and Jones streets was filled with 44
column3: 560 carloads of dirt to enlarge the site
column4: sufficient for the construction of 23 buildings. The eleven million dollar project was completed in 1927 as the fourth-largest industrial plant in Kentucky. The railroad became the largest employer in Paducah

column1: As steam locomotives were replaced through the 1940s and 1950s
column2: the Paducah shops were converted to maintain diesel locomotives. A nationally known rebuilding program for aging diesel locomotives from Illinois Central and other railroads began in 1967. The shops became part of the Paducah and Louisville Railway in 1986. In the early 21st century
column3: they are operated by VMV Paducahbilt.

column1: At the outset of the Civil War
column2: Kentucky attempted to take a neutral position. However
column3: when a Confederate force occupied Columbus
column4: a Union force under General Ulysses S. Grant responded by occupying Paducah. Throughout most of the war
column5: Col. Stephen G. Hicks was in charge of Paducah
column6: and the town served as a massive supply depot for Federal forces along the Ohio
column7: Mississippi

column3: under the terms of General Order No. 11
column4: US forces required 30 Jewish families to leave their long-established homes. Grant was trying to break up a black market in cotton
column5: in which he suspected Jewish traders were involved. Cesar Kaskel
column7: dispatched a telegram of complaint to President Lincoln and met with him. As there were similar actions taken by other Jewish businessmen and loud complaints by Congress about the treatment of their constituents
column8: Lincoln ordered the policy to be revoked within a few weeks.On March 25
column10: Confederate Gen. Nathan Bedford Forrest raided Paducah as part of his campaign northward from Mississippi into Western Tennessee and Kentucky. He intended to re-supply the Confederate forces in the region with recruits
column14: and especially to disrupt the Union domination of the regions south of the Ohio River. Known as the Battle of Paducah
column15: the raid was successful in terms of the re-supply effort and in intimidating the Union
column16: but Forrest returned south. According to his report
column17: "I drove the enemy to their gunboats and fort; and held the city for ten hours
column18: captured many stores and horses; burned sixty bales of cotton
column21: bringing out fifty prisoners."  Much of the fighting took place around Fort Anderson on the city's west side
column22: in the present-day Lower Town neighborhood; most buildings in the neighborhood postdate the war
column23: as most of the neighborhood was demolished soon after the battle in order to deny any future raids the advantage of surprise that they had enjoyed during the battle. Among the few houses that were not destroyed is the David Yeiser House
column24: a single-story Greek Revival structure.Later having read in the newspapers that 140 fine horses had escaped the raid
column25: Forrest sent Brigadier General Abraham Buford back to Paducah
column26: to get the horses and to keep Union forces busy there while he attacked Fort Pillow in Tennessee. His forces were charged with a massacre of United States Colored Troops among the Union forces whom they defeated at the fort. On April 14
column28: Buford's men found the horses hidden in a Paducah foundry
column29: as reported by the newspapers. Buford rejoined Forrest with the spoils
column30: leaving the Union in control of Paducah until the end of the War.

column2: on January 21
column4: the Ohio River at Paducah rose above its 50-foot flood stage
column5: cresting at 60.8 feet on February 2 and receding again to 50-feet on February 15. For nearly three weeks
column7: 000 residents were forced to flee or to stay with friends and relatives in higher ground in McCracken or other counties. The American Red Cross and local churches provided some shelters. Buildings in downtown Paducah still bear historic plaques that define the high water marks.

column1: Driven by 18 inches of rainfall in 16 days
column2: along with sheets of swiftly moving ice
column3: the Ohio River flood of 1937 was the worst natural disaster in Paducah's history and elsewhere in the Ohio Valley. The earthen levee was ineffective against this flood. As a result
column4: Congress authorized the United States Army Corps of Engineers to build the flood wall that now protects the city.

column2: the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission selected Paducah as the site for a new uranium enrichment plant. Construction began in 1951 and the plant opened for operations in 1952. Originally operated by Union Carbide
column3: the plant has changed hands several times. Martin Marietta
column4: its successor company Lockheed-Martin
column5: and now the United States Enrichment Corporation have operated the plant in turn. The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE)
column7: remains the owner. The plant was closed in June 2013
column8: and the Department of Energy began the process of decontaminating and shutting down the facilities.

column1: Paducah has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) with four distinct seasons and is located in USDA hardiness zone 7a. Spring-like conditions typically begin in mid-to-late March
column2: summer from mid-to-late-May to late September
column3: with fall in the October–November period. Seasonal extremes in both temperature and precipitation are common during early spring and late fall; severe weather is also common
column4: with occasional tornado outbreaks in the region. Winter typically brings a mix of rain
column7: with occasional heavy snowfall and icing. The city has a normal January mean temperature of 34.6 °F (1.4 °C) and averages 13 days annually with temperatures staying at or below freezing; the first and last freezes of the season on average fall on October 25 and April 8
column10: and humid with a July daily average of 78.9 °F (26.1 °C) and drought conditions at times. Paducah averages 48 days a year with high temperatures at or above 90 °F (32 °C). Snowfall averages 9.1 inches (23 cm) per season
column11: contributing to the annual precipitation of 49.1 inches (1
column12: 250 mm). Extremes in temperature range from 108 °F (42 °C) on July 17
column16: 1985. Paducah is prone to river flooding from the Ohio River
column17: which is currently ongoing as of late February 2018
column18: with the river expected to crest at 49 feet on February 28.

column1: Paducah has been part of the UNESCO Creative Cities Network in the category of craft and folk art since November 2013.

column2: the Paducah Wall to Wall mural program was begun by the Louisiana mural artist Robert Dafford and his team on the floodwall in downtown Paducah. They have painted more than 50 murals addressing numerous subjects
column3: including Native American history
column4: industries such as river barges and hospitals
column6: the historic Carnegie Library on Broadway Street

column9: photographer Jim Roshan documented the painting of the Lewis and Clark Expedition mural during the America 24/7 project. One of the images was used in the book Kentucky24/7
column10: published in 2004.By 2008 the mural project was completed and being maintained. Muralist Herb Roe returned to the city each year to repaint and refurbish the panels. Roe is the only muralist associated with the project to have worked on all of the panels. Roe added a new mural to the project in the summer of 2010. It shows the 100-year history of the local Boy Scout troop
column11: Troop 1. Troop 1 is one of only a handful of troops who share their centennial with that of the national scouting organization itself. The dedication for the mural was held on National Scout Sunday
column14: artist Char Downs debuted the newest addition to the Wall to Wall mural program: a series of murals of award-winning quilts on the floodwall facing Park Street. Downs invested nearly 500 hours recreating Caryl Bryer Fallert-Gentry’s historic award-winning quilt Corona II: Solar Eclipse—the first quilt in the series—in her studio in Paducah’s Lower Town Arts District.

column1: The Paducah Art Alliance has a program of Artist in Residencies to bring respected artists in to the city. In 2018 British Artist Ian Berry came and put on an exhibition to great acclaim. Ian is famed around the world with his art in denim
column2: and fitted in with the textile art that Paducah is known for.

Paducah's Artist Relocation Program was started to offer incentives for artists to relocate to its historic downtown and Lower Town areas. The program has become a national model for using the arts for economic development. It has received the Governors Award in the Arts
column3: the Distinguished Planning Award from the Kentucky Chapter of the American Planning Association
column4: the American Planning Association's National Planning Award
column6: the Kentucky League of Cities' Enterprise Cities Award.

column2: home of the Artist Relocation Program

column4: efforts were made to preserve the architectural character
column5: and historic Victorian structures were restored in the older parts of the city. The artists' housing program contributed to that effort and became a catalyst for revitalizing the downtown area. The Luther F. Carson Center for the Performing Arts was completed in downtown Paducah in 2004.

column1: Paducah is one of only two cities named in the world-famous song "Hooray for Hollywood"
column2: which is used as the opening number for the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences Awards (the Oscars). The 1937 song

column6: Hollywood. They come from Chilicothes and Padukahs..."

column1: Paducah was home to professional baseball's minor league Class D Kentucky–Illinois–Tennessee League (or KITTY League) Paducah Paddys (1903)

column7: Paducah Polecats (1911)

column11: the ballpark has served as the home venue for Paducah Tilghman High School and American Legion Post 31 baseball teams
column12: as well as various special baseball games and tournaments. In recent years

column1: The Paducah International Raceway is a 3/8-mile motorsport racetrack built in 1972.

Paducah operates under a council–manager form of city government. The Paducah Board of Commissioners is made up of the mayor and four commissioners elected at-large by the citizens on a non-partisan basis. The mayor is elected for a four-year term and commissioners each for a two-year term. The mayor and council select and appoint a city manager to operate the city.
Paducah Public Schools operates public schools serving most of the City of Paducah. Three K-5 elementary schools
column2: Clark Elementary School
column3: McNabb Elementary School and Morgan Elementary School
column4: serve the city. All district residents are zoned to Paducah Middle School and Paducah Tilghman High School.Parts of the city and surrounding county are instead served by the McCracken County Public Schools. Concord Elementary School and Reidland Elementary/Intermediate serve students through the 5th grade; Lone Oak Elementary School and Hendron–Lone Oak Elementary School end at the third grade
column5: with 4th and 5th grade students in those schools' attendance zones attending Lone Oak Intermediate School. Middle school students in those areas may be zoned into Heath
column7: or Reidland Middle School. The county district began operating a single
column8: consolidated McCracken County High School on August 9
column9: 2013. The Paducah city district did not participate in this consolidation and Paducah Tilghman High School remains separate.

column1: Paducah is also home to two private school systems
column2: St. Mary High School and Community Christian Academy.

column1: The Paducah-McCracken County Riverport Authority was established in 1964 by the legislative bodies of the County of McCracken and the City of Paducah under an equal ownership agreement. The Riverport Authority is a quasi-government agency that provides essential maritime services for the rural regions of Western Kentucky
column2: Southern Illinois
column3: Southeast Missouri
column4: and Northwestern Tennessee.  The agency specializes in bulk
column7: and containerized cargoes
column8: and operates Foreign Trade Zone #294.  It is the only United States Maritime Administration Marine Highway Designation on the Ohio River and the only Marine Highway port on the river that is designated for container on barge service.  The authority owns the largest flat top crane in North America.

column1: Barkley Regional Airport serves the area offering regional jet service to Chicago-O'Hare with two round trips daily connecting Paducah to 150 domestic and 19 international destinations. The airport is served by one commercial airline
column2: United Express.

column1: Interstate 24 is a four-lane remote freeway that routes west to St. Louis and east to Nashville. The highway has a business loop that runs through downtown Paducah.
Interstate 66 was planned to enter the city from the south and follow I-24 east to Eddyville
column2: where it would then follow the existing Western Kentucky Parkway; however
column3: after a Tier 1 environmental impact study (EIS) conducted by the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and the Illinois Department of Transportation under the 66 Corridor Study was cancelled on August 6
column6: the I-66 Trans America Highway project as a whole was officially cancelled.

column1: Interstate 69 will follow the route of the existing Purchase Parkway to the south and east of Paducah

column3: it will connect the city north to Indianapolis and south to Memphis.
